docs.lead_paragraph: After a nurse at a Dallas hospital contracted Ebola, medical experts have begun to suggest that it might be better to transfer patients to designated centers with special expertise.

headline.main: Questions Rise on Preparations at Hospitals to Deal With Ebola
headline.print_headline: Questions Rise on Preparations at Hospitals to Deal With Ebola

docs.abstract: Experience of Emory University Hospital in Atlanta in caring for three Ebola patients calls into question oft-repeated assurances from federal health officials that most American hospitals can safely treat disease; transmission of virus to Dallas nurse Nina Pham has also raised questions about general level of preparedness in hospitals around the country; medical experts have begun to suggest it may be better to transfer patients to designated centers with expertise in treating Ebola.
docs.snippet: After a nurse at a Dallas hospital contracted Ebola, medical experts have begun to suggest that it might be better to transfer patients to designated centers with special expertise.

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Jim Yong Kim, the World Bank president, has driven the normally lumbering bank to act on Ebola with uncharacteristic speed and become a key figure in the crisis.

headline.main: Head of World Bank Makes Ebola His Mission
headline.print_headline: A Bank Chief Makes Ebola His Mission

docs.abstract: World Bank president Dr Jim Yong Kim, frustrated with slow global response to Ebola outbreak, has made fighting epidemic his mission, driving bank to act on Ebola with uncharacteristic speed; bank has committed $400 million to fighting disease.
docs.snippet: Dr. Jim Yong Kim, the World Bank president, has driven the normally lumbering bank to act on Ebola with uncharacteristic speed and become a key figure in the crisis.

docs.lead_paragraph: Health workers reported for duty at Liberia's hospitals on Monday, largely defying calls for a strike that could have further hampered the country's ability to respond to the worst Ebola outbreak in history.

headline.main: Liberia Avoids Mass Hospital Strike Amid Ebola
headline.print_headline: Liberia Avoids Mass Hospital Strike Amid Ebola

docs.snippet: Health workers reported for duty at Liberia's hospitals on Monday, largely defying calls for a strike that could have further hampered the country's ability to respond to the worst Ebola outbreak in history.

docs.lead_paragraph: Italy legalized marijuana for medical use last year, but the high cost of buying legal pot in a pharmacy meant few people signed up. Now, the government has found a solution: get the army to grow it.

headline.main: To Grow Cheap Marijuana, Italy Calls in the Army
headline.print_headline: To Grow Cheap Marijuana, Italy Calls in the Army

docs.snippet: Italy legalized marijuana for medical use last year, but the high cost of buying legal pot in a pharmacy meant few people signed up. Now, the government has found a solution: get the army to grow it.

docs.lead_paragraph: New questions emerge after Thomas Eric Duncan’s family released medical records about the Dallas hospital that sent Mr. Duncan home after his first visit to its emergency room on Sept. 25.

headline.main: Ebola Victim’s Family Blames Hospital and State
headline.print_headline: Ebola Victim’s Family Blames Hospital and State

docs.abstract: Relatives of Thomas Eric Duncan, Liberian man who became first to die of Ebola in United States, are denouncing treatment he received at Texas Health Presbyterian Hospital in Dallas, claiming that he was cremated without their knowledge or permission and given substandard care because he was African.
docs.snippet: New questions emerge after Thomas Eric Duncan’s family released medical records about the Dallas hospital that sent Mr. Duncan home after his first visit to its emergency room on Sept. 25.

keywords.value: Texas Department of State Health Services
keywords.name: organizations

byline.contributor: Manny Fernandez reported from Dallas, and Julie Bosman from Chicago.
byline.original: By MANNY FERNANDEZ and JULIE BOSMAN

docs.lead_paragraph: Born and raised in Guatemala, Dr. Daniel Sanchez navigated a summer of big changes and fast learning as a first-year resident at Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center in Brooklyn.
docs.abstract: Dr Daniel Sanchez, who was born in Guatemala, is among 21 doctors in three-year internal medicine program at Woodhull Hospital in Brooklyn; program, at community hospital that serves borough's poorest residents, is trial by fire for medical school graduates from all over world.
docs.snippet: Born and raised in Guatemala, Dr. Daniel Sanchez navigated a summer of big changes and fast learning as a first-year resident at Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center in Brooklyn.

docs.lead_paragraph: The drug is the first complete treatment for the disease that requires a single daily pill.

headline.main: Harvoni, a Hepatitis C Drug From Gilead, Wins F.D.A. Approval
headline.print_headline: Gilead’s Hepatitis C Drug Wins F.D.A. Approval

docs.abstract: Gilead Sciences' hepatitis C drug Harvoni wins approval from Food and Drug Administration; treatment is first for the disease that requires only a once-a-day pill.
docs.snippet: The drug is the first complete treatment for the disease that requires a single daily pill.

docs.lead_paragraph: Federal health officials will require temperature checks for the first time at five major American airports for people arriving from the three West African countries hardest hit by the deadly Ebola virus.

headline.main: Newly Vigilant, U.S. Will Screen Fliers for Ebola
headline.print_headline: Newly Vigilant, U.S. Will Screen Fliers for Ebola

docs.abstract: Federal health officials will require temperature checks for the first time at five major American airports for people arriving from three West African countries hardest hit by Ebola epidemic; however, health experts say measures are more likely to calm worried public than to prevent people with Ebola from entering country; move comes after death of Thomas Eric Duncan, Liberian man who was the first person diagnosed with Ebola in the United States.
docs.snippet: Federal health officials will require temperature checks for the first time at five major American airports for people arriving from the three West African countries hardest hit by the deadly Ebola virus.

keywords.value: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
keywords.name: organizations

byline.contributor: Michael D. Shear and Jeremy W. Peters contributed reporting from Washington, Manny Fernandez from Dallas and Donald G. McNeil Jr. from New York.

docs.lead_paragraph: A Spanish nursing assistant may be the first person in the ongoing epidemic to catch Ebola outside of Africa, but she probably won't be the last, experts warn.

headline.main: WHO: Spain's Ebola Case Won't Be Last in Europe
headline.print_headline: WHO: Spain's Ebola Case Won't Be Last in Europe

docs.snippet: A Spanish nursing assistant may be the first person in the ongoing epidemic to catch Ebola outside of Africa, but she probably won't be the last, experts warn.

docs.lead_paragraph: Do-it-yourself flu vaccine? It could happen. Military folks who squirted vaccine up their noses were as well-protected as others who got it from health workers, a study found.

headline.main: Do-It-Yourself Flu Vaccine? Study Shows It Works
headline.print_headline: Do-It-Yourself Flu Vaccine? Study Shows It Works

docs.snippet: Do-it-yourself flu vaccine? It could happen. Military folks who squirted vaccine up their noses were as well-protected as others who got it from health workers, a study found.
